title: Algebra II
teaser: Students explore polynomials, rational and radical relationships, trigonometry and functions and make inferences and conclusions from data.

children.title: Polynomial, Rational, and Radical Relationships
children.teaser: Students connect polynomial arithmetic to computations with whole numbers and integers.

children.title: Polynomials-From Base Ten to Base X
children.teaser: Students discover how polynomial arithmetic is analogous to operations with integers.

children.title: Successive Differences in Polynomials
children.teaser: Students write explicit polynomial expressions for sequences by investigating successive differences of those sequences.

children.title: The Multiplication of Polynomials
children.teaser: Students develop the distributive property for application to polynomial multiplication.

children.title: The Division of Polynomials
children.teaser: Students develop a division algorithm for polynomials.

children.title: Comparing Methods-Long Division, Again?
children.teaser: Students connect long division of polynomials with the long division algorithm of arithmetic.

children.title: Putting It All Together
children.teaser: Students perform arithmetic operations on polynomials and write them in standard form.

children.title: Dividing by x-a and by x+a
children.teaser: Students work with polynomials with constant coefficients to derive polynomial identities.

children.title: Mental Math
children.teaser: Students perform arithmetic by using polynomial identities to describe numerical relationships.

children.title: The Power of Algebra-Finding Primes
children.teaser: Students apply polynomial identities to the detection of prime numbers.

children.title: Radicals and Conjugates
children.teaser: Students convert expressions to simplest radical form.

children.title: The Power of Algebra-Finding Pythagorean Triples
children.teaser: Students explore differences of two squares identity in the context of finding Pythagorean triples.

children.title: The Special Role of Zero in Factoring
children.teaser: Students construct a polynomial function that has a specified set of zeroes with stated multiplicity.

children.title: Factoring-It's Use and It's Obstacles
children.teaser: Students discover that factored polynomials can be used to solve equations and sketch graphs of polynomial functions.

children.title: Overcoming Obstacles in Factoring
children.teaser: Students factor certain forms of polynomial expressions by using the structure of the polynomials.

children.title: Mastering Factoring
children.teaser: Students use the structure of polynomials to identify factors.

children.title: Graphing Factored Polynomials
children.teaser: Students use the factored forms of polynomials to find zeroes of a function.

children.title: Structure in Graphs of Polynomial Functions
children.teaser: Students graph polynomial functions and describe end behavior based upon the degree of the polynomial.

children.title: Modeling with Polynomials-An Introduction
children.teaser: Students transition between verbal, numerical, algebraic, and graphical thinking in analyzing applied polynomial problems.

children.title: Modeling with Polynomials-An Introduction (Continued)
children.teaser: Students interpret and represent relationships between two types of quantities with polynomial functions.

children.title: Overcoming a Second Obstacle in Factoring-What If There’s a Remainder?
children.teaser: Students rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms, including representing remainders when dividing.

children.title: The Remainder Theorem
children.teaser: Students know and apply the remainder theorem and understand the role zeroes play.

children.title: Modeling Riverbeds with Polynomials
children.teaser: Students learn to fit polynomial functions to data values.

children.title: Modeling Riverbeds with Polynomials (Continued)
children.teaser: Students model a cross-section of a riverbed with a polynomial function and estimate fluid flow.

children.title: Solving and Applying Equations-Polynomial, Rational, and Radical
children.teaser: Students solve polynomial, rational, and radical equations and apply to real-world contexts.

children.title: Equivalent Rational Expressions
children.teaser: Students write  rational expressions in equivalent forms.

children.title: Comparing Rational Expressions
children.teaser: Students compare rational expressions.

children.title: Multiplying and Dividing Rational Expressions
children.teaser: Students multiply and divide rational expressions.

children.title: Adding and Subtracting Rational Expressions
children.teaser: Students add and subtract with rational expressions.

children.title: Solving Rational Equations
children.teaser: Students solve rational equations.

children.title: Word Problems Leading to Rational Equations
children.teaser: Students solve word problems using models.

children.title: A Focus on Square Roots
children.teaser: Students solve simple radical equations.

children.title: Solving Radical Equations
children.teaser: Students develop facility in solving radical equations.

children.title: Linear Systems in Three Variables
children.teaser: Students solve linear system algebraically.

children.title: System of Equations
children.teaser: Students solve systems of linear equations in two variables.

children.title: Graphing Systems of Equations
children.teaser: Students practice graphical interpretations of systems of equations.

children.title: The Definition of a Parabola
children.teaser: Students construct a parabola and understand this geometric definition of the curve.

children.title: Are All Parabolas Congruent
children.teaser: Students perform geometric operations on arbitrary parabolas.

children.title: Are All Parabolas Similar
children.teaser: Students apply the geometric transformation of dilation.

children.title: A Surprise from Geometry-Complex Numbers Overcome All Obstacles
children.teaser: Students solve polynomial equations involving complex numbers.

children.title: A Third Obstacle to Factoring-What If There Aren’t Real-Number Solutions?
children.teaser: Students understand that there may be no real solution to an equation.

children.title: A Surprising Boost from Geometry
children.teaser: Students understand complex numbers as a superset of the real numbers

children.title: Complex Numbers as Solutions to Equations
children.teaser: Students solve quadratic equations with real coefficients.

children.title: Factoring Extended to the Complex Realm
children.teaser: Students solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have complex solutions

children.title: Obstacles Resolved -A Surprising Result
children.teaser: Students understand the fundamental theorem of algebra.

children.title: Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students define sine, cosine, and tangent as well as the co-functions.

children.title: The Story of Trigonometry and Its Contexts
children.teaser: Students study graphs of the functions to discover properties of the trigonometric functions.

children.title: Ferris Wheels-Tracking the Height of a Passenger Car
children.teaser: Students sketch the graph of a nonlinear relationship between variables.

children.title: The Height and Co-Height Functions of a Ferris Wheel
children.teaser: Students model and graph two functions.

children.title: The Motion of the Moon, Sun, and Stars-Motivating Mathematics
children.teaser: Students explore the historical context of trigonometry.

children.title: From Circle-ometry to Trigonometry
children.teaser: Students use special triangles to geometrically determine the values of sine and cosine.

children.title: Extending the Domain of Sine and Cosine to All Real-Numbers
children.teaser: Students define sine and cosine as functions for all real numbers measured in degrees.

children.title: Why Call It Tangent?
children.teaser: Students define the tangent function and understand the historic reason for its name.

children.title: Secant and the Co-Functions
children.teaser: Students use reciprocal relationships to relate the trigonometric functions to each other.

children.title: Graphing the Sine and Cosine Functions
children.teaser: Students graph the sine and cosine functions and analyze the shape of these curves.

children.title: Awkward! Who Chose the Number 360, Anyway?
children.teaser: Students explore horizontal scaling.

children.title: Basic Trigonometric Identities from Graphs
children.teaser: Students observe identities from graphs of sine and cosine.

children.title: Understanding Trigonometric Functions and Putting Them to Use
children.teaser: Students use trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena.

children.title: Transforming the Graph of the Sine Function
children.teaser: Students formalize the period, frequency, phase shift, midline, and amplitude of a general sinusoidal function.

children.title: Ferris Wheels-Using Trigonometry Functions to Model Cyclical Behavior
children.teaser: Students review how changing parameters affects the graph.

children.title: Tides, Sound Waves, and Stock Markets
children.teaser: Students model cyclical phenomena using trigonometric functions.

children.title: Graphing the Tangent Function
children.teaser: Students graph the tangent function.

children.title: What Is a Trigonometric Identity?
children.teaser: Students prove the Pythagorean identity.

children.title: Proving Trigonometric Identities
children.teaser: Students prove simple identities involving the sine function, cosine function, and secant function.

children.title: Trigonometric Identity Proofs
children.teaser: Students see derivations and proofs of the addition and subtraction formulas for sine and cosine.

children.title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
children.teaser: Students synthesize and generalize what they have learned about a variety of function families.

children.title: Real Numbers
children.teaser: Students extend the meaning of an exponential expression to allow for rational and irrational exponents.

children.title: Integer Exponents
children.teaser: Students review and practice applying the properties of exponents for integer exponents.

children.title: Base 10 and Scientific Notation
children.teaser: Students review place value and scientific notation.

children.title: Rational Exponents-What are 2^(1/2) and 2^(1/3)?
children.teaser: Students calculate quantities that involve positive and negative rational exponents.

children.title: Properties of Exponents and Radicals
children.teaser: Students rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

children.title: Irrational Exponents—What are 2^sqrt(2) and 2^(pi)?
children.teaser: Students extend the domain of the function to all real numbers.

children.title: Euler's Number, e
children.teaser: Students calculate the average rate of change of a function.

children.title: Logarithms
children.teaser: Students discover the logarithmic properties.

children.title: Bacteria and Exponential Growth
children.teaser: Students solve simple exponential equations numerically.

children.title: The "What Power" Function
children.teaser: Students calculate a simple logarithm using the definition.

children.title: Logarithms-How Many Digits Do You Need?
children.teaser: Students use logarithms in real-world context.

children.title: Building Logarithmic Tables
children.teaser: Students construct tables of logarithms.

children.title: The Most Important Property of Logarithms
children.teaser: Students discover the reciprocal property of logarithms.

children.title: Properties of Logarithms
children.teaser: Students practice a theoreticalapproach to demonstrating six basic logarithm properties.

children.title: Changing the Base
children.teaser: Students understand how to change logarithms from one base to another.

children.title: Solving Logarithmic Equations
children.teaser: Students solve simple logarithmic equations.

children.title: Why Were Logarithms Developed?
children.teaser: Students use logarithm tables to calculate products and quotients of multi-digit numbers without technology.

children.title: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions and their Graphs
children.teaser: Students graph logarithmic functions, identifying key features.

children.title: Rational and Irrational Numbers
children.teaser: Students interpret logarithms with irrational values.

children.title: Graphing the Logarithm Function
children.teaser: Students identify key features of the graphs of logarithmic-functions.

children.title: Graphs of Exponential Functions and Logarithmic Functions
children.teaser: Students compare graphs of exponential functions corresponding logarithmic functions.

children.title: The Inverse Relationship Between Logarithmic and Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students see logarithmic function base b and the exponential function base b are inverse functions.

children.title: Transformations of the Graphs of Logarithmic and Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students study transformations of the graphs of logarithmic functions.

children.title: The Graph of the Natural Logarithm Function
children.teaser: Students graph the natural logarithm function, understanding its relationship to other base b logarithm functions.

children.title: Choosing a Model
children.teaser: Students analyze data and find a function to use as a model.

children.title: Using Logarithms in Modeling Situations
children.teaser: Students use logarithms to solve exponential equations analytically, and express the solution as a logarithm.

children.title: Bean Counting
children.teaser: Students use properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions.

children.title: Solving Exponential Equations
children.teaser: Students apply properties of logarithms to solve exponential equations.

children.title: Geometric Sequences and Exponential Growth and Decay
children.teaser: Students use model situations of exponential growth and decay.

children.title: Percent Rate of Change
children.teaser: Students develop a general growth/decay rate formula.

children.title: Modeling with Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students create exponential functions to model real-world situations.

children.title: Newton's Law of Cooling, Revisited
children.teaser: Students apply knowledge of exponential/logarithmic functions and transformations of functions to a contextual situation.

children.title: Geometric Series and Finance
children.teaser: Students apply understanding of models and exponential growth to financial literacy.

children.title: The Mathematics Behind a Structured Savings Plan
children.teaser: Students derive the sum of a finite geometric series formula.

children.title: Buying a Car
children.teaser: Students use the sum of a finite geometric series formula to develop a formula.

children.title: Credit Cards
children.teaser: Students compare payment strategies for a decreasing credit card balance.

children.title: Buying a House
children.teaser: Students model the scenario of buying a house.

children.title: The Million Dollar Problem
children.teaser: Students use geometric series.

children.title: Inferences and Conclusions from Data
children.teaser: Students build a formal understanding of probability.

children.title: Probability
children.teaser: Students explore chance experiments, sample space, and events such as unions, intersections, and complements.

children.title: Chance Experiments, Sample Spaces, and Events
children.teaser: Students calculate the probability of events defined in terms of unions, intersections, and complements

children.title: Calculating Probabilities of Events Using Two-Way Tables
children.teaser: Students calculate probabilities given a two-way table of data.

children.title: Calculating Conditional Probabilities and Evaluating Independence Using Two-Way Tables
children.teaser: Students interpret probabilities, including conditional probabilities, in context.

children.title: Calculating Conditional Probabilities and Evaluating Independence Using Two-Way Tables (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use a hypothetical 1000 two-way table to calculate probabilities of events.

children.title: Events and Venn Diagrams
children.teaser: Students represent events by shading appropriate regions in a Venn diagram.

children.title: Probability Rules
children.teaser: Students use the complement rule to calculate the probability of the complement of an event

children.title: Probability Rules (Continued)
children.teaser: Students interpret probabilities in context.

children.title: Modeling Data Distributions
children.teaser: Students use smooth curves to model given data distributions.

children.title: Distributions-Center, Shape, and Spread
children.teaser: Students describe data distributions in terms of shape, center, and variability.

children.title: Using a Curve to Model a Data Distribution
children.teaser: Students draw a smooth curve that is used as a model for given data distribution.

children.title: Normal Distributions
children.teaser: Students calculate 𝑧-scores.

children.title: Normal Distributions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use tables and technology to estimate the area under a normal curve.

children.title: Drawing Conclusions Using Data from a Sample
children.teaser: Students explore the purposes and differences of various data samples.

children.title: Types of Statistical Studies
children.teaser: Students distinguish between observational studies, surveys, and experiments.

children.title: Using Sample Data to Estimate a Population Characteristic
children.teaser: Students differentiate between a population characteristic and a sample statistic.

children.title: Sampling Variability in the Sample Proportion
children.teaser: Students understand the term sampling variability.

children.title: Sampling Variability in the Sample Proportion (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand the term sampling variability in the context of estimating a population proportion.

children.title: Margin of Error When Estimating a Population Proportion
children.teaser: Students use data from a random sample to estimate a population proportion.

children.title: Margin of Error When Estimating a Population Proportion (Continued)
children.teaser: Students calculate and interpret margin of error in context.

children.title: Sampling Variability in the Sample Mean
children.teaser: Students learn how simulating samples gives information abouthow sample means vary.

children.title: Sampling Variability in the Sample Mean (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand sampling variability in the context of estimating a population mean.

children.title: Margin of Error When Estimating a Population Mean
children.teaser: Students know the relationship between sample size and margin of error.

children.title: Margin of Error When Estimating a Population Mean (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use a formula to calculate the margin of error from a single random sample.

children.title: Evaluating Reports Based on Data from a Sample
children.teaser: Students interpret margin of error from reports that appear in newspapers and other media.

children.title: Drawing Conclusions Using Data from an Experiment
children.teaser: Students draw conclusions based on data from a statistical experiment.

children.title: Experiments and the Role of Random
children.teaser: Students identify the response variable and treatments in a statistical experiment.

children.title: Differences Due to Random Assignment Alone
children.teaser: Students investigate differences in group means when one group is randomly divided into two groups.

children.title: Ruling Out Chance
children.teaser: Students are introduced to randomization testing.

children.title: Ruling Out Chance (Continued...)
children.teaser: Students consider if certain Diff values may be unusual or extreme.

children.title: Ruling Out Chance (Continued)
children.teaser: Students perform the five steps of a randomization test.

children.title: Drawing a Conclusion from an Experiment
children.teaser: Students carry out a statistical experiment to compare two treatments.

children.title: Drawing a Conclusion from an Experiment (Continued)
children.teaser: Students generate a comprehensive report.

children.title: Evaluating Reports Based on Data from an Experiment
children.teaser: Students critique and evaluate statements in published reports.
